abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Palestinian Reform and
            Development Plan Development Policy Grant (PRDP DPG) Project
            for West Bank and Gaza (WBG) were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the success of the PRDP DPG has provided a number
            of important lessons for future Bank operations. First and
            foremost is that for budget support operations to be
            successful, they must support the Government's agenda
            and not an agenda imposed from outside. The DPG directly
            supported the PRDP that was formulated by the Palestinian
            Authority (PA) after extensive consultations with a wide
            variety of stakeholders including government agencies, civil
            society and donors. Thus, there has been strong buy in from
            all parties and the reforms supported by the DPG have been
            successfully implemented. The success can be traced to the
            realistic scope and timing of the reform agenda. The
            Palestinians are attempting to build a state from scratch
            while under occupation. There is an extensive agenda of
            pressing reforms. However, the PA has only a limited ability
            to implement reforms. Thus, the PA, in consultation with
            donors, has narrowed their efforts to the most critical
            reforms that are also attainable. As the reform process
            progresses and the Government builds strength, the agenda
            will become more ambitious. Reaching too far, too fast,
            could doom the reform process. Thus, successful policy
            lending must take into account the political realities faced
            by the government and requires careful timing and targeting
            of critical reforms. Another clear lesson has been the
            importance of having the Bank's task team resident in
            the WBG country office. In fragile and conflict states, the
            situation is constantly changing and government priorities
            shift rapidly. Therefore, it is necessary to maintain a
            constant dialogue with government counterparts, which
            requires the task team to be present in the country. The
            previous budget support operation in WBG suffered because it
            was managed from headquarters.
